College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Southwest Petroleum University Chengdu 610500 China The oxygen vacancies are significant defects that serve as reactive sites in several catalytic reactions. The CO2 methanation catalysts were facilely designed through tailoring the local electron density on oxygen vacancies by introducing different electron acceptors (Pr, La and Y). We prepared a series of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = rare earth element) catalysts to boost catalytic activity of CO2 methanation at low temperature. It demonstrated the concentration of oxygen vacancies could be significantly regulated by doping strategy, hence altering the local microelectronic structure of catalyst and strengthening the MSI effect. The Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst demonstrated the greatest density of oxygen vacancies and optimal CO2 methanation performance. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity achieved 84.6 % and 99.8 % at 270 °C, respectively. In situ DRIFTS revealed Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst enhanced the formate pathway. These results can provide better guidance for CO2 utilization technology to develop more efficient catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Interfacial oxygen vacancy Rare-earth element-doped CeO2 Catalytic mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Heavy dependence on fossil fuels leads to excessive CO2 emissions in the atmosphere. Rising CO2 emissions will significantly contribute to environmental pollution, encompassing global warming, ocean acidification and biodiversity depletion. In consequence, CO2 utilization technology plays a key role in achieving carbon neutrality [1]. Converting CO2 directly into high-value chemical products is currently acknowledged as the most efficient carbon reduction technique globally which can effectively alleviate the current environmental and energy crisis [2–4]. The hydrogenation of CO2 is a technique to transforms CO2 into valuable chemicals, contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions while simultaneously generating economic advantages. The Sabatier process, known as CO2 methanation (CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O, ΔH298K = -165 kJ mol-1), has garnered considerable interest for numerous decades because of its potential in CO2 hydrogenation technology. CO2 methanation technology is regarded as one of the most efficient methods for CO2 recycling. It not only aids in environmental preservation and energy transformation, but also yields significant economic advantages and promotes sustainable development. Moreover, CH4 can serve as a fuel gas and also be converted into significant chemical compounds, such as ammonia and methanol. Consequently, the advancement and application of CH4, as an essential component of green energy, has attracted significant interest [5]. CO2 methanation is an exothermic process thermodynamically and it has a strong tendency to hydrogenate to form CH4 at low temperatures (< 400 °C) [6]. On the other hand, CO2 molecules exhibit significant stability because of the double bond and require activation at high temperatures. The reaction requires a highly active catalyst to improve catalytic performance at low temperature [7,8]. Literature reported that the catalysts for CO2 methanation predominantly consist of metal-supported catalysts [9,10]. Ni metal is considered as an efficient and cheap metal center for CO2 methanation [11,12]. The efficacy of Ni-based supported catalysts is typically associated with the characteristics of the supports and the interactions between the metal and the supports [13,14]. Generally, metal oxide is one of the most commonly used metal support in catalytic reactions due to its stable structure and distinctive interaction with active metals, which offers abundant active sites for catalytic reactions. Oxygen vacancies (Ov) significantly influence catalysis by modifying the electronic structure of metal oxides, serving as active sites and enhancing catalytic efficiency. It is reported in the literature that Ni/CeO2 catalyst has a typical metal-support interface and ample oxygen vacancies (Ov) as active centers, which adjusts the local electronic structure of the catalyst and promotes the catalytic efficiency of CO2 methanation at low temperature [15,16]. In other words, the reaction rate can be effectively enhanced by activating the C=O bond on surface oxygen vacancies. Oxygen vacancies facilitate the modification of the catalyst's microelectronic structure and improve electron transport capacity [17,18]. The active local microelectronic environment at the interfacial oxygen vacancies also facilitates the enhancement of the metal-support interaction (MSI) effect, hence accelerating the CO2 methanation [19–21]. As in previous research, the support structure influences the binding strength between reaction intermediates and active sites, further impacting the catalyst's activity at low temperatures [22]. The higher concentration of oxygen vacancies on supports result in an increased number of CO2 adsorption sites and promote the transformation of more key reaction intermediate [23,24]. These findings enhance our comprehension of the catalytic process and offer novel concepts and methods for the design and development of efficient catalysts. In the previous literature, the local electron arrangement of the catalyst can be effectively changed by including atoms with different d/f electron densities, thus affecting the concentration of oxygen vacancies [25–27]. Rare earth elements (RE) are typically chosen as dopants to regulate electrons rearrangement on interfacial oxygen vacancies [28]. Therefore, introducing RE elements as the promoters facilitates oxygen vacancies to effectively activating CO2. Yan et al. [29] doped Eu3+ into CeO2 support. The Ni-CeO2 interaction can be enhanced by increasing the amount of Ni-Ov-Ce interfacial sites. G.I. Siakavelas et al. [30] prepared that Ni catalysts supported on Sm2O3-CeO2, Pr2O3-CeO2 and MgO-CeO2. Studies indicate that Sm3+, Pr3+ or Mg2+ can be effectively incorporated into the CeO2 lattice, resulting in the formation of extra oxygen vacancies. It is also found that doping elements can improve catalyst stability and inhibit nickel agglomeration and deactivation at high temperatures, hence offering insights for industrial applications. Currently, the optimal reaction temperature for CO2 methanation, as described in the majority of literature, remains over 300 °C at atmospheric pressure. the influence of oxygen vacancy concentration and its corresponding mechanism on CO2 activation remain ambiguous. In this work, we prepared Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = Pr, La and Y) and Ni/CeO2 catalyst as an efficient structured catalyst to regulate the local electron density of active sites by rare earth elements doping engineering. This strategy enhanced the metal-support interaction (MSI), which boosted CO2 activation and improved the catalytic activity of the CO2 methanation. The nanorod supports materials were Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ oxides, which were synthesized using the hydrothermal method. XRD, TPR XPS, Raman and TEM were used to reveal that the interfacial oxygen vacancies tuned the MSI of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ via regulating the local electron density. The Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst exhibited the highest oxygen vacancy concentration and best catalytic performance. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at 270 °C for Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ achieved 84.6 % and 99.8 %, respectively. Finally, in situ DRIFTS revealed that the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst with more oxygen vacancy sites enhanced formate route at lower temperature. Our catalyst design idea may be integrated with different methods including noble metal doping, crystal morphology regulation, electronic structure modulating and applied in diverse heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Which further boost the CO2 hydrogenation performance of the Ni-based catalyst and enhance the comprehension of the interfacial CO2 hydrogenation mechanism. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Methods for catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ce0.90RE0.1Oδ supports The Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = Y, La and Pr) support materials were prepared by the hydrothermal method. Typically, Initially, RE (NO3)3⋅xH2O and Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O were solubilized in distilled (DI) water. The molar ratio of Ce to RE element is 0.90:0.10. Subsequently, 10M Na(OH) solution was introduced to the prepared nitrate mixed solution. and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The evenly stirred mixed precipitate solution was transferred into a 100 ml autoclave and reacted at 100 °C for 20 h, then cooled naturally. The precipitate acquired after the reaction was washed with distilled water to neutrality and dried in a drying oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried powder sample was calcined at 450 °C with rate 5 °C min-1 for 4 h and named Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ supports. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Ni/ Ce0.90RE0.1Oδ catalysts The Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved with 50 ml distilled water and then add Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ powder. The obtained mixed solution was stirred at room temperature and 80 °C for 4 h, respectively. Finally, the solid sample was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 450 °C with rate 5 °C min-1 for 4 h. The name of the sample is recorded as Ni/ Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ. The theoretical Ni loading for all samples is 10 wt %. 2.1.3 Preparation of monolithic catalyst The Ni/ Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalyst was mixed with deionized water and made into slurry by ball mill, and then coated on cordierite honeycomb ceramic substrate. The monolithic catalyst was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 450 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Catalytic performance tests The methanation reaction was tested at atmospheric pressure, with the temperature range of 200–360 °C and H2/CO2 = 4, First, the catalyst was reduced in a fixed bed reactor with pure H2 flow at 450 °C with rate 5 °C min-1 for 1 h, and then, the catalyst naturally cooled to 160 °C. The gas mixture with a cumulative flow rate of 50 ml/min–containing CO2 (20 %) and H2 (80 %) was introduced into the reactor. On-line gas chromatograph (GC 9790) was used to detect the composition of products flowing out of the reactor. The CO2 conversion ( X C O 2 ) is defined by X C O 2 = [ C O 2 ] in − [ C O 2 ] out [ C O 2 ] in and CH4 selectivity ( S C H 4 ) is defined by: S C H 4 = [ C H 4 ] out [ CO ] out + [ C H 4 ] out × 100 % The subscripts "in" and "out" indicate the inlet airflow and the outlet airflow respectively 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure characterization of catalyst Fig. 1 a illustrated the preparation process diagram for the Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalyst. The morphologies of the Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = Y, La and Pr) and Ni/CeO2 catalysts were investigated using TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) techniques. Ni and RE elements are dispersed on Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ nanorods (Figs. 1 and S1–S4). This demonstrated that we have effectively constructed the Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ supports with the RE element uniformly distributed in CeO2. The length of Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ nanorods is about 50–100 nm and the width is about 10 nm. It could be clearly observed that the length of CeO2 changes with the doping of RE (Fig. 1b–e), which suggested RE were successfully doped into the CeO2 crystal lattice and forms solid solution. Meanwhile, the lattice distances of 0.19 nm, 0.32 nm, 0.28 nm and 0.20 nm were observed (Fig. 1f−i), which were assigned to the CeO2 (110), CeO2 (111), CeO2 (100) and Ni (111) crystal planes, respectively [31,32]. The Ni particle size of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts was calculated from TEM results in Table 1 and Figs. S1–S4. The particle size of Ni particles was about 6–11 nm. XRD examination was executed to ascertain the crystal structure of the Ni/ Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = Y, La and Pr) and Ni/CeO2 catalysts. In Fig. 2 a, the diffraction peaks are distinctly present in all catalysts. The main diffraction peaks of CeO2 are 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.4° respectively. They correspond to different crystal planes of CeO2 with a face-centered cubic fluorite structure, such as (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes (PDF#34-0394) [33]. The diffraction peak at 44.5° comes from the (111) plane of Ni0 species (PDF#04-0850) [34]. The incorporation of the RE element resulted in a shift of the diffraction peaks at 28° and 47°, accompanied by a noticeable widening due to RE species doping. Combined with TEM results, this indicated that rare earth elements had been effectively incorporated into the crystal lattice of CeO2, resulting in the formation of a solid solution [35]. The Ce-O interaction can be enhanced by the Ce-O-RE solid solution and the local electron structure on the oxygen vacancies can be effectively modulated. Fig. S5 and Table 1 displayed the N2 physisorption results of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 catalysts. The type IV adsorption isotherms with an H3 hysteresis loop were observed on all catalysts, This proved that these catalysts have mesoporous structure [36]. We observed that the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst exhibited the largest specific surface area (SBET). This indicated that appropriate RE element doping increased the specific surface area of the catalysts, which facilitated the construction of dispersed active sites. The Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst also possessed a reduced pore structure, which facilitates the effective collision of reactant molecules, hence enhancing reaction efficiency. 3.2 Catalytic performance evaluation CO2 methanation performance of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts was examined in Fig. 3 . The catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2 catalyst was obviously different by doping various RE atoms. Compared with Ni/CeO2 catalyst, the activity of Ni/Ce0.90Pr0.10Oδ catalyst and Ni/Ce0.90La0.10Oδ catalyst decreased. The Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity (Fig. 3a) at 270 °C for Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ achieve 84.6 % and 99.8 %, respectively. The difference in catalytic activity among all catalysts became most apparent at 250 °C (Fig. 3b). As the temperature rised, the CO2 conversion began to decrease due to the occurrence of RWGS reactions and the CO selectivity began to increase. The Table S1 showed the performance of CO2 methanation catalysts in other studies. Compared with other catalysts for CO2 methanation in Table S1, it can be found that Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ showed the excellent catalytic performances among them. Furthermore, the high temperatures facilitate the agglomeration and sintering of the active metal Ni particles in the catalyst, resulting in catalyst deactivation and reduced catalytic performance. In order to test the long-term stability of the catalyst, the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst stability tests were performed at 270 °C (Fig. 3c). The CO2 conversion was able to maintain prominent stability even after a time on stream of 100h without obvious deactivation. This showed that Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst maintained excellent catalytic activity and stability for a long time. For used Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst, There was no obvious difference compared with fresh Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst. and only the obvious diffraction peaks of CeO2 were observed (Fig. 3d). Moreover, as shown in Fig. 3e and f, the used Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst still maintained nanorod morphology and the average particle size of Ni nanoparticles was 6.9 nm. Compared with fresh Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst (6.5 nm), there is almost no obvious change. This indicated that the Ni particles were not obvious agglomeration and sintering deactivation (Fig. 3e). Fig. S6 and Table S2 displayed the N2 physisorption results of used Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst. The specific surface area was 62.4 m²/g, which was slightly lower than fresh Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst. The pore volume and pore diameter also decreased slightly, but the overall difference was not significant. In addition, in Fig. 3i, the weight loss of catalysts below 200 °C was related to adsorbed H2O and the weight loss of catalysts (>340 °C) should be associated with carbon deposition [37–39]. Only 1.1 % weight loss was found for used Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst and carbon deposition was not obviously observed on the used Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst, which suggests Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst has excellent carbon deposition resistance and stability. The following characterization proved that Y species generated the most surface oxygen vacancies. Therefore, the microelectronic structure of the catalyst changed, leading to a significant enhancement of the metal-support interaction (MSI), which can accelerated the activation of CO2 and conversion of catalytic reaction intermediates on the surface oxygen vacancies at low temperature. 3.3 Analysis of oxygen vacancies and electronic properties The information of surface element composition and chemical state, and the existence of oxygen vacancies on Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalyst can be detected by XPS. According to the previous reports [40–42], Ce 3d XPS spectrum showed 10 groups of peaks (Fig. 4 a), among which 6 groups of peaks belong to Ce(IV) characteristics and the other peaks come from Ce(III) characteristics [43]. The fitting parameters were displayed in Table 2 . The Ce3+ / (Ce3+ + Ce4+) were related to the content of the oxygen vacancies. The findings indicated that the incorporation of certain RE elements could alter the oxygen vacancies concentration of the catalysts. It showed that the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst had the highest ratio, which suggested the most amount of oxygen vacancies. The generation of abundant oxygen vacancies on surface enhanced the microelectronic structure of the catalyst boosting CO2 adsorption and activation. Which improved the catalyst's activity at low temperatures region. As shown in Fig. 4b, the O 1s level spectra were deconvoluted into three obviously different peaks centered at 529.4∼529.6 eV, 531.4∼531.6 eV and 532.2∼533.0 eV, which were assigned to the lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancy site (OV), and chemisorbed oxygen species with the hydroxyl group on the surface (OC) [44,45]. As presented in Table 2, The relative concentration of OV were approximately evaluated using the peak area ratios of OV to the sum of OL, Ov, and OC. which are 24 %, 30 %, 25 %, and 28 % for Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ, Ni/Ce0.90La0.10Oδ, and Ni/Ce0.90Pr0.10Oδ, respectively. The results showed that the addition of particular RE elements changed the OV relative content of the catalyst. The O 1s results corresponded well with the Ce 3d results. Especially, the O 1s XPS spectra of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ shifted to lower binding energy due to alterations in electron density associated with the variation concentration of oxygen vacancies. The RE 3d XPS spectra were in Figs. S7–S9. the La 3d were displayed in Fig. S7, The La 3d5/2 peak located at 833.6 eV and La 3d3/2 peak located at 850.7 eV were attributed to La3+. Moreover, The peaks at 838.5 eV and 855.1 eV belonged to satellite peaks [46,47]. As shown in Fig. S8, the Pr 3d XPS spectrum showed four groups of peaks, in which two Pr3+ peaks with BE at 929.7 eV and 949.2 eV. The peaks centered at 933.8 eV and 954.2 eV were assigned to Pr4+ [48]. The Y 3d XPS spectra were in Fig. S9. The Y 3d5/2 peak at 156.8 eV and the Y 3d3/2 peak at 158.9 eV were belonged to Y3+ [49,50]. As displayed in Fig. 4c, the Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 exhibited three peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 spectra, which were assigned to Ni0, Ni2+ and a broad satellite respectively [51,52]. The results displayed that the addition of specific RE elements changed the electronic environment around the active metal Ni of the catalysts. Note that RE modification shifted the binding energy of Ni 2p 3/2 peaks of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ, demonstrating the existence of electronic interaction at varying levels between RE and Ni. Typically, compared with Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ displayed a higher binding energies of Ni 2p 3/2, indicating the transfer out of its p electrons [17]. In contrast, the binding energy of the O 1s spectra in Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ was lower. The observation clearly suggested that Ni loaded on Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ owned lower electron density than that on CeO2 because the electron acceptor withdrew electrons from the Ni site [17]. The interactions between metal nanoparticles and support materials significantly affect catalyst performance. Excessive interaction will alter the activity-stability tradeoff. Metal doping has demonstrated efficacy in modulating the interface between metallic nanoparticles and reducible oxidic supports, resulting in enhanced catalytic performance [53]. Combined with the highest Ov concentration on Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ, it suggested abundant oxygen vacancies by Y species doping can effectively modulate the electronic structure of the catalyst and regulate MSI effect. Appropriate electronic interaction accelerated CO2 activation and exhibited the best catalytic performance (Fig. 3). Raman spectroscopy was employed to further evaluate the effect of different ion doping on the CeO2 crystal defects. The Raman spectra of doped RE elements exhibited distinct differences. In Fig. 5 a, all of the catalysts exhibit two vibrational bands. The F2g vibration mode of the CeO2 cubic fluorite structure and defect-induced mode (D) of the cubic ceria fluoride phase were observed at ∼465 and ∼600 cm−1, respectively [54,55]. The Raman spectra in the range of 500–700 cm-1 display two bands at 547 and 606 cm-1 in Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts, The former belonged to the vibration of asymmetric oxygen vacancies, which was attributed to the change of local electronic environment around Ce atom after doping RE atom, while the peak of the latter was attributed to the intrinsic oxygen vacancies in CeO2 [25]. Compared to Ni/CeO2, the F2g modes for RE-doped catalysts appear shifted (Fig. 5b and d), indicating that RE3+ doping perturbs the local coordination of the Ce4+ centers [56,57]. Interestingly, three doping samples exhibited different Raman shifts of the Ce−O stretching vibration mode. The Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ and Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ exhibited the largest Raman shifts (Fig. 5b and d), according to the previous literature [58,59], this indicates that the local coordination environment of Ce can be altered by RE element doping and Ce-O bond interaction can be established by Y element doping. Due to the doping of RE species and loading Ni, Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ and Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts presented the obvious defect-induced peaks (Fig. 5c) and the ratios of ID/IF2g were in Table 2, which indicated that abundant oxygen vacancies were formed and suggested the interaction of Ce-O bond could be effectively enhanced with the highest Ov concentration on Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ, thus promoting the catalytic activity of catalyst. 3.4 Reducibility and basicity site studies To clarify the reducibility and basicity site of catalysts, H2-TPR and CO2-TPD experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 6 a, in comparison to CeO2 (approximately 450 °C), the initial reduction peak linked to surface oxygen species in RE-doped samples emerged at a higher temperature range of approximately 450–500 °C, suggesting that the Ce−O−RE sites created by doping demonstrated stronger interactions than the Ce−O−Ce sites [25]. In Fig. 6b, Doping various rare earth elements altered the reducibility of the catalysts. There are three main peaks over Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts [60]. We noted there was no significant variation for the α peak area attributed to the reducible adsorbed oxygen species on surface [61]. The β1 and β2 peaks observed on Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalyst were attributed to the reduction of NiO particles with different interaction between NiO and supports [62]. Among them, the β1 peak was attributed to the weak interaction between NiO particles and the Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ support. The β2 peak represented the strong interaction between NiO particles and the Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ support. Doping RE elements altered the local electrical structure of the catalyst, hence affecting its reduction performance. The hydrogen consumption of each catalyst was calculated by using CuO as standard sample in Table 3 . The β reduction peak signal of Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ migrated to a higher temperature, indicating stronger metal-support interactions. This suggested abundant oxygen vacancies concentration modulates the local electronic density of the catalyst, hence enhancing the metal-support interaction (MSI) [63]. The surface basicity of the Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts was assessed using the CO2-TPD technique. Doping various rare earth elements altered the basic site of the catalysts, hence influencing the CO2 to adsorb and activate. The strength of the adsorption sites on the catalyst surface was typically indicated by the CO2 desorption at varying temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6c, the maximum CO2 desorption on weak adsorption sites (<150 °C) had been ascribed to the interaction of bicarbonates (HCO3*) with hydroxyl groups (OH) [64,65]. The peaks at medium (150–450 °C) and high (>450 °C) adsorption sites were attributed to acid-base metal oxides and surface coordinatively unsaturated Lewis basic sites of O2-, respectively [51]. Fig. 6c clearly illustrated that the CO2 adsorption sites on Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts are predominantly located in weak sites. The catalytic activity of methanation were altered by augmenting the adsorption sites of the catalyst, particularly through the weak adsorption sites on catalysts. 3.5 Reaction mechanism in CO2 methanation The reaction mechanism of CO2 methanation catalyzed by the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 catalysts was examined utilizing in situ DRIFTS spectra. Similar vibrational features were observed on Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 catalysts and the associated reaction intermediate were illustrated in Fig. 7 . For both Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 catalysts, the signal peaks of bicarbonate and formate were clearly observed. The formate species (HCOO* 1583−1609 cm−1 and 2834−2849 cm−1) [66,67] were the predominant species. Other carbonate (CO3* 1300−1331 cm−1) [68,69] and bicarbonate (HCO3* 1617, 1409−1427, and 1439 cm−1) [68,70,71] species primarily generated by the direct bonding of CO2 with surface oxygen atoms and hydroxyl groups of supports. This indicated that the formate was pivotal intermediate species for CO2 methanation, aligning with previous studies on Ni/CeO2 catalysts [51,61,70,72]. In Fig. S10, these peaks were attributed to CO2 [73] and the peaks intensity gradually weakened with the increase of temperature. As shown in Fig. 7d and e, for Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ, it was obvious that the intensity of HCO3* peaks was higher than Ni/CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 7a and b) and more HCO3* was almost completely consumed as the elevated temperature. Meanwhile, the peak of hydroxyl groups (OH* 3550−3750 cm−1) [74] gradually decreased with increasing temperature (Fig. 7b and e). These implied that Y-doped catalysts can yield more kinds of intermediates (bicarbonate and formate) and activated CO2 was more easily to be converted into HCO3* by combining with OH*. It was noteworthy that within the examined temperature range (100−300 °C), The OH groups (3550−3750 cm-1) were consistently observable, indicating that these OH species continued to participate in the methanation process and not from H2O [36]. Clearly, for Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalysts, the HCO3* converted to HCOO* at 150 °C, compared with Ni/CeO2 catalysts at 200 °C (Fig. 7a and d). This indicated that the reaction intermediates were more readily transformed on the catalyst. The presence of Y doping generated additional oxygen vacancies, further modulating the local electronic environment of the catalyst and enhancing the adsorption and activation of CO2. Consequently, the moderate adsorption of reaction intermediates on Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst facilitated transformation at lower temperatures, thereby enhancing the catalyst's low-temperature activity. In addition, The HCOO* bands declined progressively, corresponding with the increase of the CH4 band at 3016 cm−1 in Fig. 7c and f. Which indicated that HCOO* was a crucial chemical intermediary for the synthesis of methane. What’ more, it was evident that the peak intensity of HCOO* and CH4 is higher but its generated temperature is lower on Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst. This further demonstrated that intermediates were converted at lower temperatures and CO2 methanation follows the formate path on the catalyst. As described above, this demonstrated that the HCOO* pathway predominantly participates in CO2 low temperature methanation for Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ and Ni/CeO2 catalyst. The reaction mechanism was illustrated in Scheme 1 . CO2 was initially activated on the surface oxygen vacancies to generate CO2 δ-. Then CO2 δ- combined with hydroxyl groups on the surface of the supports to form HCO3*. The hydrogen on the Ni particles assisted in the hydrogenation of HCO3* to HCOO*. As the temperature raised and the hydrogenation process continued, Finally, HCOO* is further hydrogenated to CH4. 4 Conclusions In summary, we prepared a series of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ catalysts through doping engineering and observed the CO2 methanation activity changed by electron acceptor (Pr, La, and Y) modification at low temperature. XPS, Raman, TPR demonstrated that the regulation of the local electron density on interfacial oxygen vacancies via the electron acceptor and impacted the interaction strength between active metal and support. We observed that the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst had the maximum oxygen vacancy concentration and exhibited the best CO2 methanation activity. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at 270 °C achieve 84.6 % and 99.8 %, respectively. This suggested Y species generated additional surface oxygen vacancies and regulated the local microelectronic environment of the catalyst. In situ DRIFTS revealed that the Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst promoted more HCO3* and HCOO* intermediates hydrogenation at low temperature and formate pathway was effectively enhanced. The paper presents a viable approach for the construction of robust catalysts utilizing MSI and the modulation of local electron density at the reactive active site. Appendix A. coredata.dc:description: The oxygen vacancies are significant defects that serve as reactive sites in several catalytic reactions. The CO2 methanation catalysts were facilely designed through tailoring the local electron density on oxygen vacancies by introducing different electron acceptors (Pr, La and Y). We prepared a series of Ni/Ce0.90RE0.10Oδ (RE = rare earth element) catalysts to boost catalytic activity of CO2 methanation at low temperature. It demonstrated the concentration of oxygen vacancies could be significantly regulated by doping strategy, hence altering the local microelectronic structure of catalyst and strengthening the MSI effect. The Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst demonstrated the greatest density of oxygen vacancies and optimal CO2 methanation performance. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity achieved 84.6 % and 99.8 % at 270 °C, respectively. In situ DRIFTS revealed Ni/Ce0.90Y0.10Oδ catalyst enhanced the formate pathway. These results can provide better guidance for CO2 utilization technology to develop more efficient catalysts.
